native_region: Indian Subcontinent and Southeast Asia

description.leaf_color: Bright green when young, dark green later, deciduous in summer
description.leaf_shape: Trifoliate (3 large, leathery leaflets)
description.description: Butea monosperma, popularly called 'Palas' or 'Flame of the Forest', is a medium-sized deciduous tree admired for its spectacular flowering display. During late winter to early spring (February to April), when most trees shed their leaves, Palas bursts into bloom with dense clusters of vibrant orange to scarlet pea-shaped flowers that cover the entire canopy, giving the appearance of a tree engulfed in flames. The flowers attract bees, birds, and squirrels, making it an important ecological species. The trifoliate leaves are large, leathery, and shed annually before flowering, allowing the blossoms to stand out vividly against a bare backdrop. Its rough gray bark exudes a reddish gum known as 'Bengal Kino' or 'Palas gum', which has significant medicinal and commercial uses. After flowering, the tree produces flat, thin, papery pods containing a single seed. Because of its ability to thrive in dry, poor soils, Palas is often found in tropical and subtropical dry forests, open grasslands, and village landscapes across India. Beyond its striking beauty, it holds cultural, religious, and medicinal significance, being associated with rituals, Ayurvedic medicine, and the Holi festival where its flowers are used to make natural eco-friendly colors.
description.bark: Rough, gray, with vertical cracks, exudes medicinal gum

care.water: Low to moderate, drought tolerant once established
care.sunlight: Full sun, thrives in open spaces
care.soil_type: Well-draining sandy or loamy soils, tolerates poor soils
care.fertilizer: Minimal, occasional organic compost during early growth
care.humidity: Adaptable to dry and semi-humid climates
care.pruning: Minimal pruning, only to remove dead or damaged branches

uses.medicinal: Flowers used for skin ailments and making cooling drinks; seeds are deworming agents; bark gum treats diarrhea and dysentery.
uses.culinary: Flowers used for preparing natural drinks (like 'tesu sherbet') and natural dyes.
uses.ornamental: Highly valued as a spring-flowering ornamental tree due to its striking flame-like flowers.
uses.religious: Sacred in Hindu traditions; flowers offered in worship, especially during Holi festival.

propagation.method: Seeds (commonly), root suckers, stem cuttings
propagation.season: Best during rainy season or early monsoon

environmental.carbon_sequestration: Moderate, good for dryland afforestation

safety.handling_precautions: Flower pollen may cause mild allergies in sensitive individuals

interesting_facts: Called 'Flame of the Forest' for its fiery orange-red blossoms.
Bark yields 'Bengal Kino' or 'Palas Gum', valued in traditional medicine.
Flowers are used to make natural colors for Holi festival.
Important host plant for silk-producing lac insects.
Mentioned in Sanskrit texts as 'Palasha' and linked with Lord Agni (fire god).

native_region: Indian Subcontinent and Southeast Asia

description.spread: Wide spreading canopy up to 25-30 meters
description.leaf_color: Glossy green, turns yellow before shedding
description.leaf_shape: Heart-shaped with a distinctive elongated tip
description.description: Ficus religiosa, commonly known as Pimpal or Peepal tree, is one of the most revered and ecologically important trees in India. It is a large, fast-growing deciduous tree with a broad canopy and numerous aerial roots that support its massive trunk. The tree is easily recognized by its distinctive heart-shaped leaves with a long tapering tip, which flutter in the slightest breeze, producing a soothing rustling sound. Pimpal is a long-lived species; some specimens are believed to be over a thousand years old. It sheds its leaves in late winter, followed by the emergence of fresh, bright green foliage in spring. The tree produces small, round figs in pairs that ripen from green to purple, serving as food for birds, bats, and squirrels. Ecologically, it is considered a 'keystone species' that sustains biodiversity by providing shade, shelter, and nutrition. Culturally, the Pimpal is sacred in Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism—Gautama Buddha attained enlightenment under a Peepal tree, hence it is often called the 'Bodhi Tree'. The tree is commonly planted near temples and in villages as a symbol of longevity, wisdom, and spirituality.
description.lifespan: Several hundred to over a thousand years
description.bark: Light gray, smooth in young trees, becoming rough and cracked with age

care.water: Moderate, requires regular watering when young, becomes drought tolerant when mature
care.sunlight: Full sun, thrives best in open spaces with maximum exposure
care.soil_type: Prefers deep, well-draining loamy soils but adaptable to rocky and poor soils
care.fertilizer: Not demanding, occasional organic manure for young trees
care.humidity: Thrives in tropical and subtropical conditions
care.pruning: Minimal, usually done to manage size and remove weak or diseased branches

uses.medicinal: Leaves, bark, and roots are used in Ayurveda for asthma, diabetes, wounds, and digestive disorders. Latex is used for skin ailments.
uses.cultural: Regarded as sacred; worshipped daily in many Indian households and temples. Associated with rituals for prosperity and longevity.
uses.environmental: Provides dense shade, prevents soil erosion, improves air quality, and supports biodiversity.
uses.ornamental: Commonly planted in parks, temples, and avenues for its majestic appearance and spiritual significance.

propagation.method: Seeds, cuttings, or by planting aerial roots
propagation.season: Monsoon season is ideal

environmental.carbon_sequestration: Very high due to large biomass

safety.handling_precautions: Latex from leaves and bark may cause mild irritation in sensitive individuals

interesting_facts: Known as the 'Tree of Life' in India due to its longevity and benefits.
Gautama Buddha attained enlightenment under a Peepal tree at Bodh Gaya, hence called the 'Bodhi Tree'.
Produces oxygen even at night through a special type of photosynthesis (CAM pathway).
One of the fastest-growing and longest-living trees in India.
Deeply rooted in Indian traditions; often planted near temples as a sacred symbol.

native_region: Indian Subcontinent

description.spread: Massive canopy spreading over several hundred meters
description.leaf_color: Dark green, glossy on top, paler beneath
description.leaf_shape: Broad, ovate leaves with leathery texture
description.description: Ficus benghalensis, popularly known as Vad or Banyan tree, is India’s national tree and a symbol of immortality and strength. It is one of the largest and most majestic trees in the world, recognized by its enormous spreading canopy supported by hundreds of aerial roots that descend from branches and take root in the soil, forming new trunks. This unique growth pattern allows the tree to cover vast areas and live for centuries. The leaves are large, leathery, and ovate, providing dense shade. The tree produces small figs that turn from green to red when ripe, serving as food for birds, bats, and other wildlife. The Vad is considered sacred in Hinduism and is associated with Lord Vishnu and the concept of eternal life. It plays a vital ecological role by providing shelter to numerous species and maintaining microclimates in villages. Some banyan trees in India are over 200-300 years old and have become pilgrimage sites due to their cultural and spiritual significance.
description.lifespan: Several hundred years, sometimes over a thousand
description.bark: Grayish brown, rough, secretes white latex when cut

Associated with Lord Vishnu and worshipped during festivals like Vat Purnima.
Provides habitat and food for countless birds, animals, and insects.

description.leaf_color: Shiny green on top, lighter underside
description.leaf_shape: Elliptical to ovate leaves with smooth margins
description.description: Ficus racemosa, commonly known as Audumbar or Cluster Fig Tree, is a medium-sized deciduous tree revered in Indian culture and Ayurveda. It is easily identified by its unique fruiting habit—the figs grow in dense clusters directly on the trunk and main branches (cauliflorous nature), a rare phenomenon among trees. The figs are green when raw and turn reddish or purple when ripe, attracting birds, bats, and monkeys. Its bark is smooth and gray, while the leaves are broad, shiny, and leathery. The tree sheds leaves in the dry season and regenerates fresh foliage with the onset of monsoon. Culturally, Audumbar is considered sacred and is associated with Lord Dattatreya, worshipped as a divine and wish-fulfilling tree. Ecologically, it plays an important role in sustaining biodiversity, providing fruits, shelter, and microhabitats for a wide range of species.
description.bark: Smooth, grayish, exudes latex when cut

Important tree in Ayurveda, mentioned in ancient scriptures.

description.description: Mimusops elengi, commonly known as Bakul or Spanish Cherry, is a medium-sized evergreen tree highly valued for its fragrant flowers, dense foliage, and cultural significance. The tree has a rounded canopy with thick, leathery leaves that remain lush throughout the year. Its small, star-shaped, cream-white flowers bloom in clusters and exude a strong, pleasant fragrance, especially at night, making it a beloved ornamental tree. These flowers are often used in garlands, perfumes, and religious offerings. The tree also bears small, oval, fleshy fruits that ripen to yellow or orange and are edible with a sweet taste. Bakul wood is hard, durable, and traditionally used for construction and tools. The tree holds religious importance in Hinduism and Buddhism, being considered sacred and often planted near temples. Ecologically, it provides dense shade, supports pollinators with its nectar-rich flowers, and sustains birds and small mammals with its fruits.
description.bark: Dark gray to brown, rough and cracked, exudes white latex when cut

description.leaf_color: Dark green on top, pale green beneath

description.description: Terminalia arjuna, commonly known as the Arjun tree, is a large, majestic deciduous tree revered for its medicinal, environmental, and cultural significance. It is widely distributed along riverbanks, wetlands, and moist regions across the Indian subcontinent. The tree is characterized by its smooth, grey to pinkish bark that peels off in thin sheets and its spreading branches forming a broad canopy. The leaves are simple, dark green on the upper surface, and pale beneath. In summer, it bears clusters of small, white to yellowish flowers that are mildly fragrant. The fruits are distinctive, having five hard, winged ridges. Traditionally, the Arjun tree has been used in Ayurveda for centuries, especially for heart-related ailments. Its bark is a key ingredient in many herbal medicines for cardiovascular health, wound healing, and bone strength. Ecologically, the Arjun tree plays a crucial role in preventing soil erosion along riverbanks and provides habitat and food for birds, bees, and other pollinators.
description.lifespan: Several decades, often more than 100 years
description.bark: Smooth, grey to pinkish, exfoliates in thin sheets; medicinally valuable

Its fruits have five distinct wing-like ridges, making them easily recognizable.
Named after Arjuna, the warrior prince from the Indian epic Mahabharata, symbolizing strength and resilience.
Flowers attract bees and other pollinators, supporting the local ecosystem.

description.leaf_color: Glossy green when young, slightly yellowish green as they mature
description.leaf_shape: Trifoliate (each leaf with three leaflets), aromatic when crushed
description.description: Aegle marmelos, commonly known as Bel or Bael tree, is a sacred and medicinal tree widely found across India and Southeast Asia. It is a medium-sized, slow-growing deciduous tree known for its religious, cultural, and medicinal significance. The tree is easily recognized by its trifoliate leaves and fragrant, pale greenish-white flowers. Its fruit is round to oval with a hard, woody shell that turns yellowish when ripe. The pulp inside is aromatic, sweet, and highly nutritious, commonly used to prepare drinks, sherbets, and traditional medicines. The Bel tree holds great importance in Hinduism, being associated with Lord Shiva, and its leaves are considered sacred offerings in temples. Medicinally, nearly every part of the tree — roots, bark, leaves, and fruits — is used in Ayurveda for treating digestive disorders, diabetes, respiratory issues, and inflammation. The tree is highly drought-resistant, making it suitable for dry and arid regions.
description.lifespan: Long-lived, several decades to over 100 years
description.bark: Light gray, slightly rough, exudes a fragrant gum when cut

Nearly every part of the tree is used in Ayurveda for various health benefits.
Its trifoliate leaves symbolize the three functions of Lord Shiva: creation, preservation, and destruction.

native_region: Indian Subcontinent and Southeast Asia

description.leaf_color: Reddish when young, turning dark green as they mature
description.leaf_shape: Compound pinnate leaves with 2-4 pairs of leaflets
description.description: Schleichera oleosa, commonly known as Kusum, is a large, slow-growing deciduous tree valued for its medicinal, economic, and ecological importance. The tree is easily recognized by its young reddish foliage, which later turns lush green, creating a striking seasonal display. Kusum produces small yellow-green flowers followed by oval fruits containing seeds rich in oil. The seed oil, known as Kusum oil, is traditionally used for cooking, medicinal preparations, and as a base for hair oils and soaps. The tree is also a primary host for lac insects, which produce natural lac used in varnish, jewelry, and traditional crafts. Its dense, strong wood is highly durable and used for furniture, tools, and construction. Culturally, Kusum holds significance in rural economies as a multipurpose tree, providing shade, timber, oil, and income through lac cultivation. The tree thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is well-suited for afforestation and agroforestry projects.
description.bark: Grayish-brown, rough, with vertical cracks, exudes a yellowish gum when cut

care.humidity: Prefers moderate to humid climates

uses.environmental: Used in afforestation and agroforestry for soil conservation and biodiversity support.

The young reddish leaves of Kusum are highly ornamental and signal the changing seasons.
Kusum oil is traditionally used in Ayurvedic hair care and skincare products.
It is an important agroforestry tree, providing shade and improving soil quality.

description.leaf_shape: Elliptic to oblong leaves with smooth margins and aromatic oil glands
description.description: Syzygium cumini, commonly known as Jambhul or Jamun, is a fast-growing, evergreen tropical tree known for its delicious, dark purple fruits and medicinal properties. The tree has dense foliage, aromatic leaves, and smooth gray bark that peels in patches. In summer, it bears small white fragrant flowers followed by oblong berries that turn from green to deep purple when ripe. The fruit is juicy, with a sweet and slightly tangy flavor, and a distinct purple stain. Jamun is widely cultivated for its fruits, shade, and medicinal benefits, especially in managing diabetes and digestive disorders. Its wood is durable and resistant to water, making it useful in construction and agricultural implements.
description.bark: Smooth, grayish-brown, exfoliates in patches; reddish inner bark visible

description.spread: Wide, dense canopy up to 15-20 meters (50-65 feet)
description.leaf_color: Bright green
description.leaf_shape: Pinnately compound with 10-20 pairs of small, oblong leaflets
description.description: Tamarindus indica, or Chinch, is a long-lived, large evergreen tree prized for its dense foliage, which provides excellent shade, and its valuable fruit pods. It features a short, thick trunk and a broad, spreading crown that is highly resistant to wind. The tree produces small, inconspicuous yellowish flowers with orange or red streaks. Its most notable feature is the brown, pod-like legume containing a tart, fleshy, and highly acidic pulp, which is a staple ingredient in various cuisines around the world. The tamarind tree is exceptionally resilient, thriving in dry and arid conditions once established.
description.bark: Dark gray to brown, rough with fissures and scales

care.water: Low; highly drought-tolerant once established. Requires regular watering only in its juvenile stages.
care.sunlight: Full sun is essential for optimal growth and fruit production.
care.soil_type: Adaptable to a wide range, but prefers deep, well-draining loamy, sandy, or clay soils.
care.fertilizer: Generally not required for mature trees. Young trees may benefit from occasional organic compost.
care.humidity: Adaptable to both dry and humid tropical climates.
care.pruning: Minimal pruning required, mainly to remove deadwood or for structural shaping when young.

uses.medicinal: Pulp acts as a natural laxative and is used for digestive ailments. Leaf and bark extracts possess antiseptic and anti-inflammatory properties.
uses.culinary: The pulp is a primary ingredient for its sweet-sour flavor in chutneys, sauces (like Worcestershire sauce), curries, and refreshing drinks. Young leaves and flowers are also edible.
uses.ornamental: Widely planted as a majestic shade tree along avenues, in parks, and in large gardens due to its dense, drooping foliage.
uses.other: The hard, dense, and dark red wood is valued for furniture, carvings, and tool handles. Tamarind seed powder is used as a sizing agent in the textile and food industries.

propagation.method: Primarily from seeds. Grafting and air-layering are used for superior fruit-bearing varieties.
propagation.season: Monsoon season is the ideal time for sowing seeds.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: High, due to its large biomass and dense wood.

safety.handling_precautions: None specific, though the pods can be hard to crack open.

interesting_facts: The name 'Tamarind' is derived from the Arabic 'Tamar-hind', which means 'Indian date'.
Tamarind pulp is a key ingredient that gives Worcestershire sauce its distinctive tangy flavor.
The wood is highly durable and resistant to rot, making it a valuable timber.
Despite being a legume (from the pea family), it is not a significant nitrogen-fixer.
Its dense canopy provides excellent shade, making it a popular 'avenue tree' in hot, tropical climates.

native_region: Indian Subcontinent

description.spread: Broad, dense, rounded canopy of 10-15 meters
description.leaf_color: Glossy green, young leaves are reddish-brown
description.leaf_shape: Elliptic or oblong, clustered at the ends of branches
description.description: Madhuca longifolia, known as Moh or Mahua, is a fast-growing deciduous tree of immense economic and cultural importance, especially in the tribal regions of central India. It is famed for its fleshy, cream-colored, fragrant flowers that bloom at night and fall to the ground at dawn in early summer. These flowers are edible and have a very sweet taste. The tree sheds its leaves during the dry season, and the new coppery-red foliage appears before flowering. It also produces fleshy, greenish-yellow fruits, and its seeds are a source of valuable oil known as 'mahua butter'. The tree's resilience and its multiple uses make it a cornerstone of rural and forest economies.
description.bark: Dark grayish-brown, rough, with vertical cracks and fissures

care.water: Low; highly drought-resistant once established.
care.sunlight: Full sun is required for good growth and flowering.
care.soil_type: Tolerates a wide variety of soils, including poor, rocky, sandy, and saline soils.
care.fertilizer: Not demanding; thrives even in low-fertility soils.
care.temperature_range: 20-45°C (68-113°F); thrives in tropical and subtropical climates.
care.humidity: Adaptable to dry and semi-humid conditions.
care.pruning: Minimal pruning required, only to remove dead or diseased branches.

uses.medicinal: Bark is used in traditional medicine for skin ailments and rheumatism. Flowers are used as a coolant and tonic. Seed oil is applied to treat skin diseases.
uses.culinary: Sweet flowers are eaten fresh, dried, or cooked. They are famously fermented to produce a potent alcoholic beverage. The oil extracted from seeds ('mahua butter') is used for cooking.
uses.cultural_economic: Considered a sacred tree by many tribal communities. The collection and sale of its flowers and seeds is a primary source of livelihood, earning it the name 'Tree of Life' for these communities.
uses.other: The oil cake residue is used as a bio-fertilizer. The wood is hard and durable, used in construction and for making carts.

propagation.method: Primarily from seeds. Can also be propagated by stem cuttings.
propagation.season: Seeds must be sown immediately after collection during the monsoon as they lose viability quickly.
propagation.success_rate: Moderate to high with fresh seeds

environmental.carbon_sequestration: High due to its fast growth and large biomass.

safety.toxic_to_humans: Flowers and processed oil are safe. Excessive consumption of the alcoholic beverage can be harmful. Raw seeds may have toxic properties.
safety.handling_precautions: The seed oil cake contains saponins which are toxic to fish and should be handled accordingly.

interesting_facts: The flowers bloom at night and carpet the ground beneath the tree at dawn, where they are collected.
Bats are the primary pollinators of the Mahua tree, attracted by the strong scent of the nocturnal flowers.
It is a vital source of food, fuel, and income for tribal communities in central India.
The seeds yield an edible fat, known as 'mahua butter', which is also used in skincare and as a lamp oil.
The flowers are highly nutritious and are fermented to create a popular traditional alcoholic drink called 'mahua'.

native_region: Coastal regions of East Africa, India, Southeast Asia, and Australia

description.leaf_color: Dark green, glossy, and leathery
description.leaf_shape: Large, ovate to elliptical with distinctive, fine parallel veins
description.description: Calophyllum inophyllum, commonly known as Undi, is a slow-growing, majestic evergreen tree often found along coastal shores. It is characterized by its low-branching, wide-spreading canopy, which provides deep shade. The tree has thick, rough, grayish-brown bark and produces clusters of fragrant, white flowers with prominent yellow stamens. Its most valuable part is the fruit, a round, green drupe containing a large nut, from which the highly-prized Tamanu oil is extracted. Due to its high tolerance for salt, wind, and sandy soil, it is an important species for coastal afforestation and beautification.
description.bark: Thick, grayish-brown, rough, and deeply fissured

care.water: Moderate; highly drought and salt tolerant once established.
care.sunlight: Full sun is preferred for best growth.
care.soil_type: Thrives in well-draining sandy or loamy soils; ideal for coastal areas.
care.fertilizer: Generally not required, as it adapts well to nutrient-poor coastal soils.
care.temperature_range: 20-35°C (68-95°F); it is a tropical tree and not frost-tolerant.
care.humidity: Prefers high humidity typical of coastal environments.
care.pruning: Minimal pruning is needed, mostly to remove dead branches or for shaping.

uses.medicinal: The oil from the seeds (Tamanu oil or Undi oil) is world-renowned in cosmetics and traditional medicine for its remarkable skin-healing, anti-inflammatory, and moisturizing properties.
uses.ornamental: Widely planted as a shade and ornamental tree along coastlines, in parks, and avenues due to its beautiful foliage and fragrant flowers.
uses.environmental: Excellent for coastal windbreaks, stabilizing sand dunes, and preventing soil erosion. It's a key species in coastal ecosystem restoration.
uses.other: The wood is hard, durable, and water-resistant, traditionally used for boat building (especially keels), construction, and furniture. The seed oil is also being explored as a biofuel.

propagation.method: Primarily from seeds extracted from the fallen fruit.
propagation.season: Best sown during the monsoon season.
propagation.germination_time: Long and variable, ranging from 30 days to several months.
propagation.success_rate: Moderate; fresh seeds have a higher chance of germination.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: Moderate

safety.toxic_to_pets: Parts of the plant, especially the fruit/seed, are reported to be toxic if ingested.
safety.toxic_to_humans: The fruit and seeds are considered inedible and potentially toxic. The oil is strictly for external/topical use.
safety.handling_precautions: Tamanu oil should not be ingested.

interesting_facts: The oil from its seed, Tamanu oil, is often called 'green gold' due to its potent skin regenerative properties.
Its scientific name *Calophyllum* is Greek for 'beautiful leaf', referring to its large, ornamental leaves.
The tree is considered sacred in many Pacific cultures and was often planted around temples.
Its ability to withstand salt spray and grow in pure sand makes it a pioneer species for coastal habitats.
The wood is so durable in water that it was the preferred material for making the keel of traditional boats.

native_region: Indian Subcontinent and parts of Southeast Asia

description.leaf_color: Dark green on top, pale and finely hairy underneath
description.leaf_shape: Large, simple, oblong or obovate leaves clustered near the ends of branches
description.description: Semecarpus anacardium, known as Bibba or the Marking Nut Tree, is a deciduous tree native to the hotter parts of India. It is infamous for its fruit, which consists of a fleshy, edible orange-red receptacle (a 'false fruit') and a black, heart-shaped nut. The shell of this nut contains a potent, black, oily resin that is highly corrosive and vesicant (blister-causing). This resin has been traditionally used as an indelible ink and plays a significant role in Ayurvedic medicine, but only after a rigorous purification process. Due to its toxicity, the tree and its nuts must be handled with extreme caution.
description.bark: Dark brown to blackish, rough, exfoliating in irregular flakes

care.water: Low; it is a hardy, drought-tolerant species.
care.sunlight: Prefers full sun but can tolerate partial shade.
care.soil_type: Grows in a wide variety of soils, including poor, rocky, and lateritic soils.
care.fertilizer: Generally not required, as it is well-adapted to low-nutrient conditions.
care.temperature_range: 20-45°C (68-113°F); thrives in tropical and subtropical climates.
care.humidity: Adaptable to both dry and moist deciduous forest conditions.
care.pruning: Not a common practice; only needed to remove dead or damaged wood.

uses.medicinal: A highly potent medicinal plant in Ayurveda. The purified nut is used to treat arthritis, tumors, and skin diseases. IMPORTANT: The nut is poisonous and must undergo a specific detoxification process ('Shodhana') by experts before any medicinal use.
uses.other: The black resin from the nut shell provides a permanent, black ink for marking cloth, giving the tree its name. The fleshy, swollen fruit stalk (receptacle) is edible and sweet, but must be separated from the toxic nut with care.

propagation.method: Propagated from seeds (the nuts).
propagation.season: Seeds are best sown during the monsoon season.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: Moderate

safety.toxic_to_pets: Yes, highly toxic. All parts, especially the nut's resin, can cause severe reactions if touched or ingested.
safety.toxic_to_humans: Yes, highly toxic and dangerous. The raw nut's resin is extremely corrosive. Direct contact causes severe, painful blisters and dermatitis. Ingestion can be fatal.
safety.handling_precautions: EXTREME CAUTION IS REQUIRED. Never handle the nuts or any part of the tree with bare hands. Wear thick protective gloves and eye protection. Fumes from burning the wood or nuts are also highly toxic and can cause severe respiratory and skin reactions.

interesting_facts: It gets its name 'Marking Nut Tree' because the resin was used by 'dhobis' (launderers) as an indelible ink to mark clothing.
In Ayurveda, it is classified as an 'Upavisha' (a semi-poisonous substance) that is a powerful medicine only after purification.
It belongs to the same plant family as cashews, mangoes, and poison ivy, which are all known to contain allergenic compounds.
The potent resin has been criminally misused to create artificial bruises on the skin.
While the nut is highly toxic, the fleshy stalk it's attached to is sweet and edible, but requires careful separation.

native_region: Western Ghats of India, Sri Lanka

description.leaf_color: Shiny dark green on top, paler underneath
description.leaf_shape: Thick, leathery, simple, elliptic to oblong leaves
description.description: Mammea suriga, locally known as Surangi or Suriga, is an evergreen tree native to the Western Ghats of India and Sri Lanka. It is widely admired for its fragrant flowers, which are small, creamy-white, and bloom in profusion during the summer. The tree produces round to ovoid fruits with a yellowish-brown rind and sweet aromatic pulp containing one or more seeds. Traditionally, the tree has been valued for its ornamental, cultural, and medicinal significance.
description.bark: Dark brown to gray, rough, with vertical fissures

care.water: Moderate; requires regular watering during establishment, drought-tolerant once mature.
care.sunlight: Thrives best in full sunlight but tolerates partial shade.
care.soil_type: Well-drained lateritic, loamy, or sandy soils.
care.fertilizer: Responds to organic compost or manure during the growing season.
care.humidity: Favors humid conditions typical of coastal and Western Ghats regions.
care.pruning: Minimal; done to shape the tree or remove damaged branches.

uses.medicinal: Traditionally, parts of the tree are used in folk medicine for treating skin ailments, headaches, and fever. The fragrant flowers are also considered to have soothing properties.
uses.other: The fragrant flowers are commonly used in making garlands and hair decorations, especially in Konkan and coastal Karnataka. The tree is also cultivated as an ornamental for its beauty and fragrance.

propagation.method: Propagated mainly through seeds; vegetative propagation possible but less common.
propagation.season: Seeds are best sown at the beginning of the monsoon season.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: Moderate

safety.toxic_to_pets: Not reported as toxic, but fruits and seeds should not be given to pets without caution.
safety.toxic_to_humans: Generally safe; fruits are edible. Seeds may be bitter and are not commonly consumed.
safety.handling_precautions: No special precautions required, except ensuring fruits are properly ripened before eating.

interesting_facts: Surangi flowers are highly fragrant and are used in traditional garlands during festivals and weddings.
In Konkani and coastal Karnataka culture, Surangi flowers are worn by women in their hair as a natural perfume.
The fruits resemble small mangoes and contain sweet aromatic pulp.
It is considered an important ornamental tree in the Western Ghats region.
The tree flowers profusely during summer, filling the air with its sweet fragrance.

native_region: Tropical Americas; widely cultivated in India and Southeast Asia

description.leaf_color: Bright green, turning yellowish before shedding
description.leaf_shape: Bipinnate, with many small oblong leaflets
description.description: Caesalpinia pulcherrima, commonly known as Sankasur, Peacock Flower, or Dwarf Poinciana, is a striking ornamental shrub or small tree. It is admired for its flamboyant clusters of red, orange, or yellow flowers with long, showy stamens. The plant is fast-growing, drought-tolerant, and thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. It is often planted in gardens, parks, and along roadsides for its beauty and hardiness.
description.bark: Grayish-brown, smooth to slightly rough

care.water: Low to moderate; drought-tolerant once established.
care.sunlight: Requires full sunlight for best flowering.
care.soil_type: Well-drained sandy or loamy soils; tolerates poor soils.
care.fertilizer: Occasional organic compost or balanced fertilizer promotes better blooms.
care.humidity: Thrives in warm, humid to semi-arid conditions.
care.pruning: Responds well to pruning; prune after flowering to maintain shape.

uses.medicinal: In traditional medicine, different parts are used as remedies for fever, bronchitis, and skin ailments. However, caution is required as seeds and roots may be toxic.
uses.other: Widely planted as an ornamental hedge, avenue tree, or in gardens for its vibrant flowers. Attracts butterflies, bees, and birds.

propagation.method: Propagated by seeds; cuttings also possible but less common.
propagation.season: Best sown at the onset of monsoon or in spring.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: Low to moderate (due to small size)

safety.toxic_to_pets: Mildly toxic; seeds and pods may cause stomach upset if ingested.
safety.toxic_to_humans: Seeds and roots are mildly toxic if eaten raw.
safety.handling_precautions: Avoid ingestion of seeds and roots. Otherwise, safe to handle.

interesting_facts: The name 'Pulcherrima' means 'most beautiful' in Latin, referring to its bright flowers.
Commonly used as a hedge plant due to its dense, thorny branches.
In many tropical regions, it flowers almost year-round.
Its bright flowers are highly attractive to butterflies and hummingbirds.
It is the national flower of Barbados, where it is known as the 'Pride of Barbados'.

native_region: South and Southeast Asia (India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Thailand)

description.leaf_color: Dark green, turning yellow before shedding
description.leaf_shape: Simple, ovate to elliptic, arranged in opposite pairs
description.description: Terminalia chebulla, known as Hirda or Haritaki, is a large deciduous tree highly valued in Ayurveda and traditional medicine. It produces small yellow-white flowers and ovoid to ellipsoidal fruits (drupes), which are harvested when green or mature. The dried fruit, called 'Hirda', is one of the three key ingredients in the famous Ayurvedic formulation 'Triphala'. It is considered a potent rejuvenative and is often referred to as the 'King of Medicines' in Ayurveda.
description.bark: Dark brown to blackish, with vertical cracks and rough texture

care.water: Moderate; requires regular watering when young, becomes drought-tolerant once established.
care.sunlight: Thrives in full sunlight.
care.soil_type: Well-drained loamy to sandy soils; tolerates poor soils.
care.fertilizer: Occasional organic compost or manure during the growing season.
care.humidity: Prefers tropical to subtropical climates with moderate humidity.
care.pruning: Minimal; prune only to remove dead or diseased branches.

uses.medicinal: Highly important in Ayurveda, Unani, and Siddha medicine. Used as a digestive aid, laxative, and rejuvenative. Traditionally prescribed for cough, sore throat, constipation, liver disorders, and as a general health tonic. One of the three fruits in Triphala (with Amla and Baheda).
uses.other: The fruit is also used in tanning leather and dyeing fabrics due to its high tannin content.

propagation.method: Propagated mainly from seeds.
propagation.season: Seeds are best sown in monsoon season.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: High (due to large size and longevity)

safety.toxic_to_pets: Generally safe in small quantities; excessive consumption of raw fruit may cause digestive upset.
safety.toxic_to_humans: Safe and widely used in herbal medicine. Excess consumption may cause diarrhea or dehydration.
safety.handling_precautions: Safe to handle; fruits are usually dried and processed before consumption.

interesting_facts: Hirda is called the 'King of Medicines' in Ayurveda due to its wide therapeutic uses.
It is one of the three fruits that make up the famous Ayurvedic formulation Triphala.
In Buddhist texts, Haritaki is revered as a divine gift of health and longevity.
The fruit is rich in tannins, gallic acid, and chebulic acid, contributing to its medicinal potency.
It is not only medicinal but also used in leather tanning and natural dyeing industries.

native_region: India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Southeast Asia

description.spread: Wide, spreading crown with dense foliage
description.leaf_color: Glossy green, turning yellow before shedding
description.leaf_shape: Large, broadly elliptic to ovate, clustered at branch ends
description.description: Terminalia bellirica, known as Behada or Baheda, is a large deciduous tree revered in Ayurveda. Its fruits are grayish and ovoid, containing a single seed. The dried fruit is one of the three ingredients in the classical Ayurvedic formulation 'Triphala' (along with Amla and Hirda). The tree is also valued for its timber, medicinal properties, and ecological importance. In Ayurveda, it is known for supporting respiratory health, digestion, and eye care.
description.bark: Ash-gray, smooth in young trees, becoming rough with age

care.water: Moderate; requires regular watering when young, drought-tolerant when mature.
care.sunlight: Prefers full sun for healthy growth.
care.soil_type: Well-drained loamy or sandy soils; tolerates lateritic soils.
care.fertilizer: Occasional organic manure or compost helps in better growth.
care.humidity: Thrives in tropical and subtropical climates with moderate humidity.
care.pruning: Minimal; done to remove dead or diseased branches.

uses.medicinal: An important plant in Ayurveda and Unani medicine. The fruit is used to treat cough, sore throat, eye diseases, and digestive disorders. A key ingredient of Triphala (with Amla and Hirda). Also used for hair growth and longevity.
uses.other: The fruit rind is rich in tannins and used in leather tanning and ink making. Wood is used for construction and firewood.

propagation.method: Propagated through seeds.
propagation.season: Seeds are best sown in monsoon season.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: High (due to large size and dense canopy)

safety.toxic_to_pets: Generally safe; excessive consumption of fruits may cause digestive upset.
safety.toxic_to_humans: Safe in medicinal use. Overconsumption may cause constipation or dryness.
safety.handling_precautions: Safe to handle; fruits are dried and processed for medicinal use.

interesting_facts: Behada is one of the three fruits in the famous Triphala formulation of Ayurveda.
Its fruits are rich in tannins and used in traditional ink preparation.
Known as 'Bibhitaki' in Sanskrit, meaning 'the fruit that keeps away diseases'.
The tree is ecologically significant, providing shade and supporting biodiversity.
Its fruits are used in both Ayurvedic and Unani medicine for respiratory and digestive health.

native_region: India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Southeast Asia

description.leaf_color: Light to dark green, turning yellowish before shedding
description.leaf_shape: Small, simple, oblong leaves arranged closely along branchlets, giving a feathery appearance
description.description: Phyllanthus emblica, commonly known as Amla or Indian Gooseberry, is a medium-sized deciduous tree widely valued in Ayurveda, Unani, and folk medicine. The tree produces small, greenish-yellow flowers and round, smooth, pale green to yellow fruits with a sour, astringent taste. The fruit is extremely rich in Vitamin C and antioxidants, making it a powerful rejuvenative. Amla is one of the three fruits in the famous Ayurvedic formulation 'Triphala' (with Hirda and Behada).
description.bark: Light gray, smooth to slightly rough, peeling in patches

care.water: Moderate; requires regular watering when young, drought-tolerant when mature.
care.sunlight: Thrives in full sunlight.
care.soil_type: Well-drained loamy, sandy, or calcareous soils.
care.fertilizer: Organic compost or farmyard manure during fruiting season increases yield.
care.temperature_range: 15-40°C (59-104°F); tolerates both dry and humid climates.
care.humidity: Adaptable to varying humidity, grows well in both dry deciduous and moist areas.
care.pruning: Prune lightly to remove dead wood and to shape the tree.

uses.medicinal: Amla is one of the most important plants in Ayurveda. The fruit is a rich source of Vitamin C, antioxidants, and polyphenols. It is used for boosting immunity, improving digestion, treating hair and skin problems, and rejuvenating the body. It is also a key ingredient of Triphala and Chyawanprash.
uses.other: Fruits are consumed fresh, pickled, candied, dried, or as juice and powder. Also used in hair oils, shampoos, and herbal supplements.

propagation.method: Propagated mainly from seeds and grafting (for superior varieties).
propagation.season: Seeds are best sown during monsoon; grafting is done in summer.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: Moderate to high (fruit-bearing tree with dense foliage)

safety.toxic_to_pets: Safe; fruits are edible for most animals in moderation.
safety.toxic_to_humans: Completely safe; widely consumed as food and medicine.
safety.handling_precautions: No special precautions required.

interesting_facts: Amla is one of the richest natural sources of Vitamin C.
It is one of the three fruits in the Ayurvedic formulation Triphala.
The fruit retains its Vitamin C content even after drying or cooking.
In Hindu tradition, the tree is considered sacred and associated with Lord Vishnu.
Amla is a key ingredient in Chyawanprash, a famous Ayurvedic health tonic.

native_region: Indian Subcontinent (India, Nepal, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Myanmar)

description.height: 15-20 meters (50-65 feet), sometimes up to 30 meters
description.spread: Wide, spreading crown with dense foliage
description.leaf_color: Dark green, slightly glossy
description.leaf_shape: Pinnate leaves with 20–30 serrated leaflets
description.description: Azadirachta indica, commonly known as Kadulimb or Neem, is a fast-growing evergreen tree native to the Indian subcontinent. It is highly valued for its medicinal, ecological, and cultural significance. Neem produces small white fragrant flowers and olive-like green drupes that turn yellow when ripe. Every part of the tree—leaves, bark, seeds, flowers, and fruits—is used in traditional medicine, agriculture, and industry. Neem is often called the 'Village Pharmacy' due to its wide range of uses.
description.bark: Reddish-brown to gray, rough, deeply fissured

care.water: Low; highly drought-tolerant once established.
care.sunlight: Requires full sunlight for healthy growth.
care.soil_type: Well-drained sandy, loamy, or lateritic soils; tolerates poor and dry soils.
care.fertilizer: Generally not required; tree grows well in low-nutrient soils.
care.humidity: Tolerant of both dry and humid climates.
care.pruning: Minimal; only to remove dead or diseased branches.

uses.medicinal: Neem is one of the most important medicinal trees in Ayurveda and Siddha medicine. Leaves, bark, and seeds are used to treat skin diseases, infections, fever, diabetes, dental problems, and as an immunity booster.
uses.other: Neem oil (from seeds) is used in natural pesticides, cosmetics, and soaps. Leaves are used to store grains as a natural insect repellent. The wood is strong and used in furniture. Neem twigs are traditionally used as toothbrushes ('Datun').

propagation.method: Propagated by seeds (fresh seeds have high viability).
propagation.season: Seeds are best sown during the monsoon season.
propagation.success_rate: High if fresh seeds are used

environmental.carbon_sequestration: High (due to large canopy and long lifespan)

safety.toxic_to_pets: Neem oil and seeds can be toxic to pets if ingested in large amounts.
safety.toxic_to_humans: Generally safe in small medicinal doses. Neem oil in high amounts can be toxic and should not be ingested.
safety.handling_precautions: Safe to handle; caution required with concentrated neem oil.

interesting_facts: Neem is often called the 'Village Pharmacy' in India due to its wide range of uses.
UNESCO declared Neem as the 'Tree of the 21st Century' for its medicinal and environmental benefits.
Neem leaves and oil are natural insect repellents and eco-friendly pesticides.
It is considered sacred in Indian culture and often planted near homes and temples.
Neem twigs ('Datun') are still widely used as natural toothbrushes in rural India.

native_region: Indian Subcontinent and Southeast Asia

description.leaf_color: Dark green on upper surface, silvery or rusty underneath
description.leaf_shape: Large, maple-like, palmate leaves (15–30 cm long)
description.description: Pterospermum acerifolium, commonly called Muchkunda or Kanakchampa, is a large evergreen tree known for its distinctive maple-like leaves and fragrant nocturnal flowers. The flowers bloom at night, spreading a sweet fragrance, and fall by morning. Its wood is light yet durable, and the tree has cultural as well as medicinal significance.
description.bark: Grayish-brown, rough, with vertical fissures

care.water: Moderate; prefers regular watering when young, drought-tolerant when mature.
care.sunlight: Full sunlight to partial shade.
care.soil_type: Well-drained loamy or sandy soils; tolerates slightly acidic soils.
care.fertilizer: Not mandatory; benefits from organic compost annually.
care.humidity: Prefers warm and humid climates.
care.pruning: Minimal; prune to remove dry or crowded branches.

uses.medicinal: Flowers are used in traditional medicine for their cooling and aromatic properties. Leaves and bark are sometimes used in folk remedies for digestive and skin-related issues.
uses.other: Wood is light but strong, used for furniture, boxes, and household purposes. Cultivated as an ornamental tree for its fragrant flowers.

propagation.method: Propagated by seeds or stem cuttings.
propagation.season: Best sown during early monsoon.

environmental.carbon_sequestration: Moderate to high (due to dense canopy and evergreen nature)

safety.toxic_to_pets: Not known to be toxic to pets.
safety.toxic_to_humans: Generally safe; not commonly consumed internally.
safety.handling_precautions: Safe to handle; flowers may cause mild allergy in sensitive individuals.

interesting_facts: Muchkunda flowers bloom at night and fall by morning, filling the ground with a fragrant carpet of petals.
Associated with King Muchukunda from the Mahabharata, after whom the tree is named.
Often planted near temples for its fragrant flowers.
The large palmate leaves are sometimes used as eco-friendly plates in rural areas.
